Description: Body sherd of Attic black-figured pottery open vessel, probably a krater; interior: glazed black; exterior: Theseus and the Minotaur; to left part of drapery held out by female onlooker; central, Theseus, to right (nose, lips, chin, part of neck, torso, left upper arm, right hand and forearm remaining), wearing flecked animal skin over chiton with dots in added red; scabbard with incised diagonals), sword in right hand, left arm extended behind Minotaur’s head (part of head and horn, neck in red, black chest remaining) facing left.
Curator's comments: Venit identifies the sherd as coming from an amphora but that seems impossible as the back of the sherd is covered in a black slip.
Bibliographic references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum (B600.47)
Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 213, no. B40)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0228) (Phase 1)
